**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a court may modify a custody or visitation order upon a showing that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and that modification is necessary in the child’s best interests.

**G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**.

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion is about removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30, in the context of joint custody. It does not construe or apply G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it articulate the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modifying custody or visitation orders. The modification discussion is framed instead through the ‘cause shown’/best interests standard under § 30 and ALI principles, so this case does not provide authority for the specific § 28 proposition stated.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of or has resided five years within this [C]ommonwealth and over whose custody and maintenance a probate court has jurisdiction shall not ... be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth ... if under [the] age [of consent], without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.” Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).

**Rosen v. Rosen**, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 67.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840.proposition: When one parent’s schedule prevents consistent care or results in custodial instability, modification may be appropriate to promote the children’s welfare.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840.support_reasoning: The case affirms that in crafting a custodial arrangement under the best‑interests standard, the judge may consider each parent’s work schedule, the amount of time the child would spend in day care, and which parent can provide more consistent weekday care. The court upholds an award giving school‑week custody to the mother because her schedule was more flexible and the father’s long hours meant the child would be in day care most of the week. While the case is not a post‑judgment modification action, it supports the broader principle that custodial changes are appropriate when a parent’s schedule limits consistent care and stability, to promote the child’s welfare.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840.relevant_excerpt: "[T]he father works long hours, often involving overtime, resulting in Kali’s spending most of her time during the week in day care; [and] the mother has more flexible hours and is able to spend more time with Kali during the weekdays; ... Kali is to spend school weekdays with her mother because her mother’s schedule was sufficiently flexible to ensure that Kali’s needs during those periods will be attended to, and because that schedule would also provide ample opportunity for the mother and daughter to spend time together."

**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (20.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

**Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1.proposition: Courts recognize that changes in employment or living conditions may constitute material changes in circumstances warranting modification if they directly affect the children’s welfare.
**Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1.support_reasoning: The case discusses what constitutes a material change in circumstances for modification of alimony and child support, focusing on the payor’s employment, earning capacity, and assets, but it does not frame this in terms of changes in employment or living conditions that directly affect the children’s welfare. The analysis is primarily about the obligor’s ability to pay, not about how changed conditions impact the children, and the court ultimately finds no material change warranting modification. Thus, it does not affirm the specific principle that changes in employment or living conditions warrant modification when they directly affect the children’s welfare.
**Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award.”

**Bluhm v. Bluhm**, 68 Mass.
